abstract: Monday’s announcement that the Citigroup chief financial officer, Sallie Krawcheck, is getting a new assignment at the firm quickly ignited speculation about who might succeed her. One name that kept popping up was Alvaro G. de Molina, who announced in December that he would step down as Bank of America‘s chief financial officer, telling The New York Times’s Eric Dash that he was “looking for something that will be more impactful.”
